channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: How the Kremlin Is Militarizing Russian Society
item.description: With a “youth army,” a cathedral honoring the military and state media promoting patriotism, the government is preparing Russians for the possibility of a fight.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko, Valerie Hopkins and Sergey Ponomarev
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: An award ceremony for a patriotic club in Vladimir, Russia.

item.title: Foreign Drones Tip the Balance in Ethiopia’s Civil War
item.description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed pulled off a stunning reversal in the year-old conflict with the help of armed drones supplied by the United Arab Emirates, Turkey and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Turkey has been supplying the Ethiopian government with drones. A Bayraktar TB2 combat drone pictured at the Incirlik air base, Turkey, in May.

item.title: Haiti Missionaries Describe Dramatic Escape From Kidnappers
item.description: The group of 12, including several children, walked 10 miles through the night. Later that day, the missionaries were on a Coast Guard flight to Florida.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:description: David N. Troyer, general director of Christian Aid Ministries, next to a group photo of the 17 freed hostages plus a family member at a news conference on Monday.

item.title: A Plan Forms in Mexico: Help Americans Get Abortions
item.description: Mexican activists plan to provide women in Texas and other U.S. states with information, support — and abortion-inducing pills.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sofía, 23, said she had an abortion with the help of a network of activists in Mexico who provide women with pills that induce abortion, and then ensure they have support through the procedure.

item.title: Egypt Sentences 3 Human Rights Activists to Prison
item.description: The verdicts suggest that the government has not scaled back its crackdown on dissent, despite efforts to improve its image.
item.dc:creator: Nada Rashwan
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah in Cairo in 2014.

item.title: Peng Shuai, Chinese Tennis Player, Denies Sexual Assault Claim
item.description: Peng Shuai said in an interview with a Singaporean newspaper that she had been misunderstood. She also said, “I’ve been very free all along.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Peng Shuai has been one of China’s highest-ranked tennis players, reaching No. 1 in doubles in 2014 and as high as 14th as a singles player.

item.title: Secret Charms and 7th Sons: ‘The Cure’ Is Alive and Well in Ireland
item.description: Belief in the benefits of the cure, a type of folk medicine that interweaves home remedies with superstition, religion and a sprinkle of magic is still a way of life in pockets of Ireland.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Gallagher performing “the cure” for a man in Pullough, in County Offaly, Ireland.

item.title: U.K. Weighing Lockdown Amid an Omicron Wave and Political Turmoil
item.description: Britain’s health secretary said on Sunday he wouldn’t rule out more restrictions before Christmas, but the prime minister would most likely face sharp pushback from his own party.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newcastle, England, on Monday. A total of 82,886 new coronavirus cases were reported across Britain on Sunday after days of record highs.

item.title: New Zealand and Other Asia Pacific Countries Respond to Omicron
item.description: New Zealand is taking measures to limit the spread of Omicron, including delaying the reopening of its borders. It has detected 22 cases of Omicron in international arrivals.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Officials at a checkpoint for people leaving the Auckland area in New Zealand last week.

item.title: Lawmakers Urge Tech Companies to ‘Mitigate Harm’ of Suicide Website
item.description: A House committee is seeking briefings from search engines and web-hosting companies whose services might have been leveraged by the site, which has been linked to numerous deaths.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel J.X. Dance and Megan Twohey
item.category: House Committee on Energy and Commerce
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, wrote in a letter to Google that the company had the ability and legal authority to steer “people who are struggling away from this dangerous website.”

item.title: A Wall Street Banker Turned to Comedy for Happiness and a Career Change
item.description: Shaun Eli Breidbart was a banker on Wall Street for 19 years but he gave up a lucrative career in favor of happiness.
item.dc:creator: Pierre-Antoine Louis
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shaun Eli Breidbart at the Broadway Comedy Club in New York, where he has performed frequently.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Another Covid Christmas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A normally bustling shopping street in the center of Amsterdam was mostly quiet on Monday. Due to a nationwide lockdown, all non-essential stores, bars and restaurants in the Netherlands will be closed until Jan. 14.

item.title: Deal With Ted Cruz Sets Stage for Russia Pipeline Fight in Early 2022
item.description: The Texas Republican leveraged his obstruction of diplomatic nominees into a Senate vote that could complicate President Biden’s efforts to defend Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Mr. Cruz agreed not to obstruct the routine confirmation of 36 of Mr. Biden’s State Department and Treasury Department nominees after a vote was set for January to sanction the Nord Stream 2 pipeline.

item.title: Donald Trump Said He Got a Booster Shot and His Supporters Booed
item.description: At an event in Houston, the former president revealed for the first time publicly that he had received the additional vaccine dose.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah and Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump speaking to supporters in Phoenix in July.

item.title: Omicron Response Divides Europe as Cases Surge
item.description: As some nations impose tough restrictions in the face of soaring cases, others, including France, are lying back for the moment.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Nicholas Casey
item.media:description: A department store in Paris on Monday. France has ruled out lockdowns, curfews or closures.

item.title: U.K. Weighs New Omicron Rules as Cases Surge
item.description: It comes as cases surge from the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Britain is one of the European countries considering new pandemic restrictions amid a surge of coronavirus cases from the Omicron variant.

item.title: N.Y.P.D. officers are again told to mask up amid Omicron surge
item.description: Employees are required to wear face masks indoors and outdoors regardless of vaccination status.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer wears a mask while working in October. The N.Y.P.D. issued new guidance on mask-wearing for its employees.

item.title: U.K. Foreign Secretary Inherits Thorny Issue: Northern Ireland Talks
item.description: Liz Truss is taking charge of Brexit talks after the surprise resignation of David Frost. If she is successful, it could give her a significant political boost.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss, Britain’s foreign secretary, in London last month. She has now been put in charge of Britain’s Brexit policies.

item.title: Larry Hogan, Governor of Maryland, Tests Positive for Covid
item.description: He said he is feeling fine and that the positive test result came as a result of routine testing.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Governor Larry Hogan speaks during President Joe Biden’s visit to Baltimore in November.

item.title: Novavax’s Covid Vaccine Is Authorized in Europe
item.description: The vaccine will be the fifth to become available in the E.U., which already has ample supplies.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health care worker administered a dose of the Novavax Covid vaccine during a Phase 3 trial at Howard University in Washington this year.

item.title: U.S. and Britain Help Ukraine Prepare for Potential Russian Cyberassault
item.description: Russia has attacked Ukraine’s power grid in the past, and experts say Moscow might take similar steps as it masses troops along the border.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The Ukrainian power grid was built in the days of the Soviet Union and is connected to Russia’s, making the software as familiar to the attackers as to its operators.

item.title: As Europe Returns Artifacts, Britain Stays Silent on the Parthenon Marbles
item.description: The Parthenon Marbles in London are likely the world’s most famous disputed museum items. Yet the British government says the sculptures’ fate isn’t its concern.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Parthenon Marbles at the British Museum in 2020. Greece’s government says the sculptures, which returned to public view this month, should be sent back to Athens.

item.title: NYC Mayor: City Needs to Move Faster to Fight Omicron
item.description: In a news conference, Bill de Blasio said the next surge would likely be large but temporary.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio, right, joined by Dave Chokshi, the city’s health commissioner, spoke about the spread of coronavirus at a news conference in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, last week.

item.title: Rafael Nadal Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
item.description: The Spanish tennis star said he was isolating at home. The test further jeopardized his hopes of playing in next month’s Australian Open.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The tennis star is isolating at home in Spain.

item.title: Pope Francis Says High Number of Domestic Violence Cases Is ‘Almost Satanic’
item.description: Francis once again decried the scourge of domestic abuse, which has increased during the months of pandemic lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis at his weekly general audience in The Vatican this month.

item.title: Israel Bars Travel to U.S. or Canada as Omicron Surges
item.description: The countries were added to Israel’s rapidly growing “red list” as Prime Minister Naftali Bennett’s government tries to slow Omicron’s spread.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Travelers exiting a coronavirus testing area at Ben Gurion International Airport in Tel Aviv, November.

item.title: The Human Toll
item.description: U.S. airstrikes have not lived up to their billing.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Aleiwi Muhammad Sultan with a friend near his home in East Mosul.

item.title: Webb Telescope Approaches Launch, With an Eye Toward Cosmic Origins
item.description: The biggest space telescope in history aims to answer astronomy’s oldest question: How did we get from the Big Bang to here?
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: The James Webb Space Telescope, with its five-layer sunshield, deployed in a facility at Northrop Grumman in Redondo Beach, Calif., last year.

item.title: Inside the Campaign to Save an Imperiled Cambodian Rainforest
item.description: Deep in the Southern Cardamom Mountains, former loggers and poachers have assumed new roles as protective rangers and ecotourism guides. Can their efforts help preserve a vast stretch of wilderness?
item.dc:creator: Francesco Lastrucci

item.title: 1946: Europe Hit By Near-Zero Temperatures
item.description: An unseasonable cold wave in many northern parts of the continent resulted in frozen waterways and deep snow.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Fears of a Christmas lockdown in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Omicron Evades Many Vaccines
item.description: And elections in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: People waiting in line for AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccines in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: Lucía Hiriart, Powerful Wife of Chile’s Dictator, Dies at 98
item.description: Her husband, Augusto Pinochet, acknowledged that she had pushed him to participate in the 1973 coup that brought him to power in 1973.
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Lucía Hiriart, the wife of the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet, in 1984. She was said to wield extraordinary power in the presidential palace during her husband’s 17-year dictatorship.

item.title: 2 Lynchings Reported at Sikh Temples in India
item.description: Enraged mobs attacked men they linked to acts of sacrilege, one at the Golden Temple, the holiest shrine for Sikhs.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Sikh guards at the Golden Temple in Amritsar, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Hamas, Claiming Victory Over Israel, Is Stuck in Same Old Cycle
item.description: Seven months after a war with Israel, hundreds are dead but otherwise little has changed. It’s a familiar pattern.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Hosam Salem for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hamas and its allies fired thousands of rockets — like this one on display Rafah, Gaza — at Israel in May.

item.title: Super Typhoon Rai's Death Toll in Philippines Is Climbing
item.description: More than 200 people are now believed to have been killed by the storm.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: Damaged homes in Cebu Province in the central Philippines, along a river swollen by rain from the typhoon.

item.title: Most of the World’s Vaccines Likely Won’t Prevent Infection From Omicron
item.description: They do seem to offer significant protection against severe illness, but the consequences of rapidly spreading infection worry many public health experts.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:credit: Joao Paulo Guimaraes/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine in Moju, Para State, Brazil, in April. AstraZeneca’s vaccine, like many other viral vector vaccines, are showing early indications that they do not prevent infection with the Omicron variant.

item.title: She Broke Japan’s Comedic Barrier Playing Drunks and Fools (Yep, Men)
item.description: Niyo Katsura has won acclaim in rakugo, a classical form of Japanese storytelling, by doing anything onstage that a man can do.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Niyo Katsura performing rakugo, a classical form of Japanese comedic storytelling, in Osaka this month. Ms. Katsura is the first woman to win a prestigious award for rakugo newcomers.

item.title: Gabriel Boric, a Former Student Activist, Is Elected Chile’s Youngest President
item.description: The millennial will play an important role in helping shape a new legal framework for a nation that has been roiled by social upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: At 35, Gabriel Boric will be the nation’s youngest leader and by far its most liberal since President Salvador Allende.

item.title: Biden to Address Nation About Omicron on Tuesday
item.description: The remarks are expected to detail how the United States will respond to the latest pandemic challenge.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks on the pandemic in January with Jeffrey D. Zients, the White House coronavirus response coordinator. He is planning to address the nation about the Omicron variant on Tuesday.

item.title: Washington State Senator Doug Eriksen Died After Covid Infection
item.description: Doug Ericksen was a Republican who helped lead opposition to Washington State’s Covid-19 emergency orders and vaccine mandates.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: State Senator Doug Ericksen in 2017. He represented Whatcom County in the northwestern corner of Washington State.

item.title: Southeast Asia's Tourist Spots Are Open, but Visitors Are Scarce
item.description: Hopes for a revival of international tourism have fizzled amid restrictions, paperwork, a lack of flights and uncertainty around the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: A tourist on the beach in Bali this month. Just 45 visitors from overseas have come to the island in Indonesia this year.

item.title: Japan Fire: Osaka Police Identify a Suspect, 61
item.description: A 61-year-old man, hospitalized after the fire at an Osaka psychiatric clinic, is being investigated on suspicion of arson and murder, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The clinic set afire on Friday was in a narrow, eight-story building in a crowded part of Osaka, Japan.

item.title: David Frost, Brexit Negotiator, Resigns in Another Blow to Boris Johnson
item.description: The move puts new pressure on the prime minister, whose leadership has been called into question by a series of setbacks, including a new wave of Covid infections.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: In his resignation letter, David Frost hinted that he had significant differences with Prime Miniister Boris Johnson over coronavirus restrictions.

item.title: With Omicron Surging, London Declares a ‘Major Incident'
item.description: The Greater London area has seen cases rise by nearly 200 percent over the last two weeks, making it the hardest hit area of Britain.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: After a 29 percent surge in hospitalizations over the past week, London alerted residents that hospitals were starting to be overwhelmed again.

item.title: Nearly a year into his presidency, Biden is again struggling to beat back a resurgent virus.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden boarding Marine One in Philadelphia on Friday.

item.title: Omicron surges, a federal mandate returns and schools get new guidance: The week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Grand Central Market in Los Angeles on Friday. A statewide mandate was put into place on Wednesday requiring Californians to wear face masks in all indoor public settings regardless of their vaccination status.

item.title: Reveling in the Joys of Books, and Reading, at a Baghdad Book Fair
item.description: Iraq is home to literary traditions ancient and modern, and to legions of avid readers who find a new book more meaningful to them than a new government.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posing for selfies in front of fake volumes glued together and arranged to spell the word “book” at the Baghdad International Book Fair.

item.title: In a France Fearful of Immigrants, Another Candidate Tacks Hard Right
item.description: Valérie Pécresse, the center-right candidate in April’s presidential election, has adopted the vocabulary of the far right when discussing immigration.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Valérie Pécresse, the candidate of the center-right Republicans for France’s presidential election next year, with supporters this month in Paris.

item.title: A surge in demand for virus tests is swamping the U.S. system.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:description: Cars lined up at a drive-through test site in Miami, Fla., on Friday.

item.title: Here’s how to use rapid home tests (once you find one).
item.dc:creator: Tara Parker-Pope
item.media:description: Irma Mazzoni handing out free rapid at-home Covid-19 test kits in Chelsea, Mass., on Friday, as part of a statewide effort to slow the spread of the coronavirus over the holidays.

item.title: Israeli Defense Officials Cast Doubt on Threat to Attack Iran
item.description: Israel has threatened military action to destroy Iran’s nuclear program if need be. But defense officials say Israel does not have the ability, at least not anytime soon.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: An Israeli Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker and F-16 fighter jets performing over Jerusalem in April. Israel wants to replace the 50-year-old refueling tankers but is unlikely to get new ones for at least three years.

item.title: Why Are So Many Canadians Moving to the Atlantic Provinces?
item.description: A Times reporter fulfills his lifelong dream of visiting Newfoundland and explores why so many Canadians are moving to the country’s Atlantic provinces.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Along the coastline in Bonavista, Newfoundland, where “come from awayers” have flocked in recent years.
